ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Linear regression, variable and model selection techniques, mixed-effects models, logistic regression, binary classification, regular expressions, data visualization, working with big data
I learned lots of new data analysis, data visualization, and data interpretation techniques that will serve me well in the future (both at Yale and beyond).
statistical knowledge, data analysis and visualization
This course was a great broad introduction to learning about typical tools employed in data analysis, which was highly engaging and informative!
A much stronger foundational knowledge in some of the most common / powerful DS methods
data analysis methods such as constructing linear models and reading its output, scraping and cleaning data, proper data exploration, different ways to evaluate a model, visualizations of data, etc.
Data analysis techniques -- some were already covered in previous S&DS classes but this class took a more applied approach, which was really helpful!
Data Analysis
Learned a lot about using R for stats

I learned how to use R-specific software such as ggplot and regular expressions, along with modeling techniques such as linear and logistic regression, LASSO, and mixed effects models. I also learned to determine whether a model is a good fit for a particular dataset.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was amazing. A huge strength is that we covered a LOT of different topics from every subject of S&DS. We did a bit of math, a bit of theoretical, a bit of applied stats, and bit of coding, a bit of visualization, and it was terrific. I really appreciated how the professor was also incredibly understanding during the pandemic, and how she and the TAs made themselves available to help us whenever we needed.
strength: really great workload with in-class activities
The course (homeworks, tests, projects, etc...) all were set up for us to reinforce the learned skills. I felt as though I could actively engage with all of them.
Thought it was an great course. Teacher helped answer questions and seemed passionate about the material. Couldve been improved if we went deeper in some of these topics.
Strength: Super nice professor

Strengths: Great course for learning. Lectures were organized for understanding and material was presented clearly. Elena is also a great lecturer that used images and other ways of presenting information to facilitate learning.

Weaknesses: I generally prefer using R markdown for data analysis so it may be useful to have had both file methods. But, this is personal preference. Also, I am not sure how useful the in-class activities and how they could be adapted for in in-person environment. I found that breakout rooms worked best for the activities.

Strengths: content is really important/applicable to many science fields (I was able to apply some of the material to my senior research), professor is really kind/understanding, and lectures are engaging
Weaknesses: seemed to fall a bit behind in assigning homework in the first half of the course, how the final course grades would be assigned (ie. curved or not, cutoffs) was ambiguous for most of the course/until the last day of classes

I think this course was really well designed! Elena's dedication to course showed through the lectures and examples she prepared, and it became clear through the course of the semester that she was invested not only in her students' academic success but also in their mental and physical well-being. If I had to name a weakness of the course, it's that I would have benefitted from slightly more frequent problem sets, which would have given me more opportunities to apply the concepts discussed in class and receive feedback on my work.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The professor and TAs were so understanding, which made learning in the pandemic really easy and good. Coding online via zoom is also a terrific strategy - it's easier to share screen and see code in R. Another positive was the recorded lectures: having everything recorded means that we can go back and re-watch lectures from the content that was more challenging, and learn the material again before midterms and homeworks. Being virtual was honestly super helpful for this!
breakout room in-class activities
The course was run very successfully online, and I appreciated how it was adapted to work well given the context.
It was solid for a virtual class.

Elena was very cognizant about pandemic changes and especially the struggles with online learning. From flexibility in live/recorded lecture to uploading lectures on time, I felt that her adaptation of the course was perfect.
Recorded lectures were helpful
I really appreciated how Elena made lecture interactive by building in time for exercises and having us work together in small groups to solve them.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Elena is an amazing person and instructor. She knows what she's talking about and really looks out for the well-being of her students.
Yes! Just a really terrific course that teaches you practical skills for S&DS that'll help you if you're planning on going into anything that requires statistics or analysis.
Yes! It's a relatively light-weight s&ds course but very practical for various use of statistics. I personally learnt things from the course that I can use in my job interviews
It is a crucial class for any student looking at data exploration/analysis as a next step.
Yes, would recommend. The teachers really great and you learn a lot of very helpful tools, which can be applied to research / industry, etc.

Yes! This course doesn't require too much prerequisites, and Elena does a really good job explaining the concepts. I found many of the tools covered immediately useful and applicable, and the material is not too challenging, which encourages actual learning. Elena is also very patient and understanding. Overall a great course with a wonderful professor.

Yes, it's a great class to take, especially if you're an older student in the S&DS major. It introduces you to some new concepts while reviews some old ones with a different, more applied approach. You walk out of the class with a more comprehensive understanding of data analysis techniques.

Yes, I think that Elena does a good job of distinguishing between the goals of machine learning and the goals of data analysis at the beginning of the course. From there, I felt that the course did not repeat the same material learned in other classes even though they were techniques. For example, we spent a lot of time on regression in this class, but viewing it from the perspective of data exploration instead of prediction was interesting.
Yes - the material is really useful in most science fields and the professor is kind

Yes! This course was the perfect introduction to data analysisit wasn't too much work, but it still covered all of the important concepts. Would highly recommend for anyone looking to explore the field!

N/A
live virtual lecture
